Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 8 hours on average
6 hours
10 hrs
Usually 4-6 for homeworks, more for exams (obviously).
10 or more hours a week
4 to 6 hours / week
5 hours
3 hours
3 hours

10+ hours per week on homework and readings
20+ hours of study prior to exams

Strengths: 1) gives you a good understanding of transmission dynamics in an accessible manner; 2) labs were helpful to learn the material 
Weaknesses: 1) Readings were unhelpful and I think the reading response questions were unnecessary;  2) went over time pretty often; 3) minuscule comment, but it would have been helpful to have consistent numbering between lectures, labs/assignments, and readings. The numbers were off and it made it difficult when going back to study.

Weakness: 8:30 AM class is brutal, I also think that more group work (possibly during lab?) might improve understanding; a lot of the math was glossed over, which I would have liked to have see, but I get that time is limited
Strengths: interesting material, Prof. Cohen is good, I like the half lecture/half lab structure

Strengths: Professor Cohen is great, super sharp, very enthusiastic, and the material is good.

Weaknesses: It would have been very helpful to have some solution sets to homework to try to model future work off of. Though the TAs were great and provided commentary, I was still left wondering if I had answered questions optimally and found it hard to prepare for exams for that reason.
too much homework assignment, a lot of repeated questions, no standard/suggested answer provided for homework assignment
Great course, learned a lot

This was a considerably difficult course, but I felt like I learned a ton. As someone with no prior modeling exposure, there was an initial learning curve. However, I felt that I could apply principles in this class to the material more and more as time went on. The weekly homeworks are great to keep you engaged, and the grading system encourages you to learn rather than to aim for the highest score possible.

Strengths: The class covers a multitude of microbial diseases in terms of the modeling procedures. 

Weakness: There is just too much homework per week to the point where I just want to get through it instead of working through each question. The labs are helpful but having less homework would be good (sometimes, it just seemed like busy work instead of actually learning anything).
Challenging course with second half being more intense than the first half. Labs were helpful in learning the material. Tests mimicked labs and homework assignments.

A ton of weekly hr that requires a deep deep understanding of the material. I would not mind if the grading was more attempt due to the difficulty, but grading on correctness is unfair. That said, I LEARNED A TON this class. This is one of the few classes where I am proud of my knowledge and work even though my grade might not be the highest. This is truly a PhD level course with the expectations and the workload but I am better for it. Would recommend, but not for the faint of heart.

The course was interesting.  However, every week we would get 12-15 pages of homework, which would take a ridiculous amount of time to complete.  You would think that as the topics got more complicated, the number of questions would decrease, but unfortunately, that is far from true.  Each week, the topics would get harder, and so would the homework questions, but the amount of questions would remain the same.

This was an interesting course that taught me a lot about infectious disease modeling. The weekly homework assignments, although sometimes long and somewhat repetitive, are helpful for reinforcing concepts learned in class. The course becomes more conceptual after the midterm, which made it somewhat difficult to know how to prepare for the final exam. The lack of answer keys for the homework could be frustrating at times if you wanted to review on your own, however the TAs and professor were very helpful and available for questions.

The homework assignments were very long, and I feel like we didn't focus on the more difficult problems in the "lab" time. The lab time was additionally confusing--I don't really think it was necessary and would have benefited more from the lecture material being spread out over two class sessions.

Great course -- incredibly helpful setup having homework reinforce the lecture material. Sometimes things felt disjointed discussing the homework one week after it was done; is it perhaps possible to discuss challenging questions from the homework the day it is due rather than one week later?

I also felt that there was not much discussion about the course readings. The readings on canvas did not match up between canvas/course syllabus/homeworks/lectures. It felt difficult to devote time to the readings as such.

The paper reviews were excellent assignments, and I felt very prepared to interpret and critique the models.

The content was presented in a highly understandable way. The homework and the labs while good in theory, were incredibly long and repetitive. felt more like busy work than something that was actively helping us understand the material.

Interesting topics and taught well overall. I think sometimes he talked about things that we needed prior knowledge about (like some 2nd years had taken classes about some of the topics) but he never examined us on those higher order topics so that was nice. It was hard to use some of the homeworks to study because they are structured in a way that is made for R and not really explaining concepts we should be getting.

requires you to think critically
course moves quickly so have to grasp the material quickly 
going over more difficult homework questions in class

I really enjoyed the class and I found that it advanced my understanding of infectious disease transmission and my ability to critically read and understand academic papers. Learning about the theoretical dynamics of what we observe in practice enhanced my education and I hope to use the skills and concepts I learned in the future! My only critique would be that answer keys for homeworks and practice questions would have been appreciated, especially for questions that involved actual calculations on exams and not just theoretical frameworks like we saw on the homework

The homeworks/labs were extremely helpful in learning the material and thinking critical about the topics, however they were fairly challenging each week. Being the homework during classroom lab sessions, having office hours, and encouraging collaboration to solve the hw problems was beneficial is obtaining an overall understanding of the questions asked. The two review papers presented an opportunity to use what we had learned to evaluate a real model, however I would have also appreciated some more practice examples from that weeks lectures to better understand the concept since we did have a lab assignment due that week.

I thoroughly enjoyed this course. I learned a lot and each day in lecture was useful. However, the homeworks can be unnecessarily long. I'd recommend cutting those back a few pages, especially when we need to turn in physical copies and printing it not free.
The lengthy homeworks were way too much, particularly since the feedback we received on them was minimal.

from easy to hard
learn sophisticated dynamic models

Great class - I learned so much! Prof Cohen is a great lecturer, and he breaks down difficult concepts into manageable parts. The weekly homeworks were definitely way too long though (often 10-15 pages). Many of the questions seemed very repetitive and almost too straightforward to really be a question.

This is a course that is packed full of material, which makes it challenging but also interesting. I think a decent amount of course material could be excised to create a more focused and enjoyable course without sacrificing anything of value.
Ted is great; very approachable and intelligent. He really wants you to understand the material and will explain things in different ways if you are struggling with the material.
Prof. Cohen generally explains things very well and has helpful, relevant examples for teaching, plus he's always willing to stop to answer questions.

Strengths: Professor Cohen is very quick and enthusiastic about the material.

Weaknesses: His slides are good but they could be more explicit in showing his work.
excellent instructor
Great instructor
Ted is incredibly smart and his lectures were always engaging. For a difficult course, his insights and ability to answer questions effectively were much appreciated.
He was so passionate about the topic and it seemed like he really wanted to support us in modeling!
Did a good job teaching complex material in as simple a manner as possible.

Great guy 10/10 Had trouble sharing some of the difficult information in lecture and spent a good deal on derivations. But, as this is not a Biostats class, it might have been better to focus specifically on the modeling components and not how specific equations or terms were derived.

Dr. Cohen was very available in office hours for questions. He was patient and willing to explain / review anything that was confusing. I think sometimes the pacing of the class was a bit off, in that he spent a long time on fairly simple concepts, while he moved quickly through more complex concepts. This was especially true at the end of the course when it felt like we rushed through some material without an opportunity to really learn it in detail or work through it on a homework set
Prof Ted Cohen is an engaging lecturer. The slides can stand alone as course notes, which is useful, but his explanations in the lecture really add richness to the slides.
You did great Ted!
Instructure is knowledgable but is not great at explaining more theoretical concepts in a way that the application is understood.
Dr. Cohen was always supportive understanding that this class can be challenging for some and always encouraged to seek help were needed.
Ted is great. I thought he explained things well and was helpful with any questions I had.
Very informative
Great lecturer! Made things very clear to understand, good slides

Ted is a very smart and caring instructor, but I sometimes felt like his way of explaining course concepts was only making things more opaque. When I met with him during office hours (twice) he came off as impatient, frustrated, and overworked. In this way he was definitely a negative outlier among the professors I've had at YSPH. I would recommend students meet with the Teaching Fellows instead.
I would recommend this course. Wish Ted hadn't been on sabbatical last year, I would have very much appreciated taking this course earlier in my MPH, especially if doing the modeling concentration.
Interesting material, 8:30 classes are terrible but worth it for sure
If you like modeling and infectious diseases!
Need answer keys for assignment. Workload is high.
good
I would highly recommend it regardless of your specific interests or department. It gives you a robust quantitative exposure, and although difficult, you come away with a lot after the class is over.
For students who want to learn more about transmission modeling (and okay to take if you're not EMD!).

I would recommend the course to a fellow student that is highly interested in modeling. I would not recommend the course for a student who is not interested in pursuing any further education or work in disease modeling.
A ton of work but a necessary class for non-modeling or modeling students in infectious diseases. Again, not for the faint of heart and get ready to work. But you'll learn a lot.
Very time intensive course.  It was interesting, but it was difficult to follow at times.
I would recommend this course. It is interesting to learn general approaches to modeling, and especially useful for individuals interested in infectious disease

I would highly recommend this course to a student interested in learning how to evaluate transmission dynamics models of infectious disease. This course is taught at a fairly high level, but serves as an excellent introduction to infectious disease modeling. I feel much more comfortable when I encounter a model in the literature.
It's a little harder than other courses but the information is valuable and interesting. I would recommend it.
I would recommend if you are interested in modeling and disease dynamics

This was a great challenging class. It did require a great deal of work but was definitely worth it as I learned a great deal about dynamic models and have been able to apply what I learned in other classes.
Highly recommend if you want to do disease dynamic model research

This is a very good, very challenging course for students interested in modeling infectious disease transmission. The material is focused not on programming but on box-and-arrow diagrams and ordinary differential equations to model disease dynamics, with R programming used to illustrate the abstract concepts, so keep this in mind if you are considering taking the course.
